unnormalised: ## Are Your Desi Gadgets Safe From "Cyber Chor"? A Humorous Look at Cybersecurity in India
normalised: are your desi gadgets safe from cyber chor? a humorous look at cyber security in India

unnormalised: Namaste, tech enthusiasts! In the digital Bharat of today, we're all happily swiping, tapping, and sharing memes faster than you can say "aloo paratha." But amidst this tech-fueled euphoria, a sneaky "cyber chor" lurks, ready to pounce on our data like a hungry crow on a samosa. So, let's talk cybersecurity, but with a desi twist – because who says tech talk can't be spiced up with a little humor?
normalised: namaste, tech enthusiasts! in the digital Bharat of today, we are all happily swiping, tapping, and sharing memes faster than you can say aloo paratha. but amidst this tech-fueled euphoria, a sneaky cyber chor lurks, ready to pounce on our data like a hungry crow on a samosa. so, let us talk cyber security, but with a desi twist – because who says tech talk cannot be spiced up with a little humor?

unnormalised: Firstly, consider your trusty smartphone. That shiny device costing upwards of Rs. 25000, holding your entire life – from embarrassing childhood photos to your bank details! Are you using "123456" as your password? Bhai, even my nani knows that's weaker than chai without sugar! Opt for a strong password, like "SharmaJiKaBetaNeverGetsHacked@2024". Okay, maybe not that long, but you get the idea. And for extra security, enable that fingerprint scanner or face unlock. Treat it like your mother's gold bangles - don't leave it lying around unprotected!

unnormalised: Now, let's discuss those "free Wi-Fi" hotspots. Tempting, aren't they? Especially when your mobile data is slower than a government office during lunch hour. But beware! These networks can be cyber-crooks’ dens. Imagine a hacker sitting in a coffee shop, sipping masala chai, and snooping on your browsing history. Stick to trusted networks or, better yet, use a VPN – consider it your digital "helmet" protecting you from online road accidents. My friend Ravi learned this the hard way after his FB account was hacked after logging into a "Free WiFi" at Delhi Airport costing him quite a lot of embarrassment.

unnormalised: And those app permissions? Remember that game you downloaded promising endless fun, and you just clicked “Allow” on everything without reading? You might have just given some random app in China access to your contacts, location, and photos. Treat app permissions like you're negotiating with a stubborn auto-rickshaw driver. Only give what's necessary. Does your "bhajan" app really need access to your camera? I think not!

unnormalised: Also, keep your software updated. Think of software updates as the "health tonic" for your gadgets. They patch up vulnerabilities and keep those cyber pests away. Ignoring them is like skipping your morning yoga – you'll regret it later. Most gadgets and PCs costing over ₹40000 get regular updates anyway.

unnormalised: Let's not forget the dreaded phishing emails. These digital "chelas" are designed to trick you into revealing your personal information. Be wary of emails from unknown senders promising you've won a "massive lottery" or offering "urgent bank refunds." Remember the golden rule: if it sounds too good to be true, it probably is. My colleague, Anita, almost fell for a scam promising her ₹5000000 if she just provided her bank details. Luckily, she consulted with the IT guy before doing anything drastic.

"StrongPassword@2024"? Just kidding!
